<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_unmap:
```c
void metal_dma_unmap(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg,
		  int nents)
{
	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/*If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);

	if (!dev || !dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap || !sg)
		return;
	dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg, nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_dma_unmap:
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_R 1
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (!dev || !dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap || !sg)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The controlling expression is not invariant: it depends on the function parameters (dev, sg) and the runtime value of dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap, so it can evaluate differently on different calls. Therefore Rule 14.3 is not violated. (A violating scenario would be using a constant controlling expression such as if (1) or if (0) or a macro that always expands to a compile-time constant.)
